name: K2-187
scenarioDescription:
The K2-187 Exoplanetary System

K2-187 is a star with 0.98 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.92 times its radius. It is located 1087.76 light years away from the solar system.

K2-187 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

K2-187 b

K2-187 b was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2018-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.02 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 0.77 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-187.

The mass of K2-187 b is 1.81 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-187 b is 1.3 that of Earth. At 1.81 Earth masses, K2-187 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

K2-187 c

K2-187 c was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2018-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.87 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-187.

The mass of K2-187 c is 3.97 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-187 c is 1.8 that of Earth. At 3.97 Earth masses, K2-187 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

K2-187 d

K2-187 d was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2018-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.15 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-187.

The mass of K2-187 d is 15.36 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-187 d is 3.17 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, K2-187 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

K2-187 e

K2-187 e was discovered by the K2 observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2018-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.61 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, K2-187.

The mass of K2-187 e is 7.68 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-187 e is 2.38 that of Earth. At 7.68 Earth masses, K2-187 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system K2-187, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by K2.
